---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

The main new declaration created in this pull request is `Polynomial.hilbertPoly_linearMap`, which is the `F`-linear map `fun (p : F[X]) => Polynomial.hilbertPoly p d`.

nodes.body:
### PR summary [a50718cb71](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/19897/commits/a50718cb71a5ccfacb7c7e00bc42189c91eb3088)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ hilbertPoly_add_nat`
`+ hilbertPoly_linearMap`
`+ hilbertPoly_smul_nat`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>
I think it's fine to keep every `F` implicit.
I don't understand the purpose of `_nat` in the name.

> I don't understand the purpose of `_nat` in the name.

The purpose of naming it in this way is to follow the style of the lemmas `Polynomial.hilbertPoly_zero_nat`, `Polynomial.hilbertPoly_poly_zero`, etc. (which are also in the file RingTheory/Polynomial/HilbertPoly.lean).

Observe that if we only name the above lemma as `Polynomial.hilbertPoly_add`, then if later we have some lemma
```
lemma Polynomial.hilbertPoly_? (p : F[X]) (d e : ) :
    Polynomial.hilbertPoly p (d + e) = ... := ...
```
then the new lemma will also have the name `Polynomial.hilbertPoly_add`, which will cause some trouble.

If we name preserve the name `Polynomial.hilbertPoly_add_nat`, then when we need to have some lemma
```
lemma Polynomial.hilbertPoly_? (p : F[X]) (d e : ) :
    Polynomial.hilbertPoly p (d + e) = ... := ...
```
we can name the new lemma as `Polynomial.hilbertPoly_poly_add`, so the new lemma won't be confused with the old lemma.

I think that `hilbertPoly_add` is probably better. We can cross the `d + e` bridge when we come to it. We have `Polynomial.eval_add` for example, and `eval` takes two inputs. I would also suggest changing `hilbertPoly_zero_nat` to `hilbertPoly_zero`. I'm pretty sure that we have had instances in the past where we've had nameclashes for functions with two input, but I'm also pretty sure that we didn't fix them by adding the name of the type to the name of the declaration, so I'm not sure there's a historical precedent for this convention.
Oh but in fact this already happens here, because we have `_zero_nat` and `_poly_zero`. I think we need to ask for advice here about a good naming convention.

> `zero_apply` and `apply_zero`, maybe?

And shall I change the declaration `Polynomial.hilbertPoly_poly_succ` into `Polynomial.hilbertPoly_apply_succ`, and `Polynomial.hilbertPoly_add_nat` into `Polynomial.hilbertPoly_add_apply`?
It's probably best to be consistent, I guess.

Wouldn't it be more useful to have
```lean
variable (F) in
noncomputable def hilbertPoly_linearMap (d : ) : F[X] [F] F[X] where
  toFun p := hilbertPoly p d
  map_add' p q := hilbertPoly_add_nat p q d
  map_smul' r p := hilbertPoly_smul_nat r p d
```
?

pullRequest.title: feat(RingTheory/Polynomial/HilbertPoly): `Polynomial.hilbertPoly_linearMap`
